Language Arts

Grammar Workshop - Pages 124-125

1 More journal

Journal Writing Reminder

Some students are making the same mistakes each week, so please read this carefully before writing your next journal.

Make sure you write in the past tense. Journals are about things that already happened.

Your journal needs a clear beginning, middle, and ending. Think about what happened first, next, and last.

Write slowly and clearly so your writing is neat and easy to read.

Try to make your journal more exciting for the reader. Use sensory words to describe what you saw, heard, smelled, tasted, or felt. Add details, describing words, humor, and creativity to bring your story to life.

Below is an example journal you can use as a model.

Last weekend was very busy and fun. On Saturday morning, I went to the dentist. The chair was uncomfortable, and I could hear strange buzzing sounds, which made me a little nervous. After that, I felt relieved it was finished.

Later that day, I took my son to a bookstore in Seoul. The store was bright and quiet, and it smelled like new books. We walked around the shelves, flipping through colorful covers and talking about which books looked interesting.

On Sunday, we went to a local kids café called Jumping Monster. It was loud, energetic, and full of laughter. Even though I am the father, I like to play too. I played Nintendo badminton, a fast car racing game, and even sang in the singing room. By the end of the day, I was tired but happy, and it was a weekend I really enjoyed.
